writing_prompt: When Arthur stumbles upon the scars Merlin has been hiding, he demands answers—but the truth behind them reveals more than either of them expected, leaving their bond forever changed.
story:
Arthur hadn’t meant to find out. In fact, he had been oblivious to the secret Merlin had carried for years, hidden beneath layers of cheerful banter and clumsy servitude. It was only when Merlin had slipped, quite literally, during one of their training sessions, that Arthur had glimpsed the truth.

Merlin had been attempting to dodge one of Arthur’s playful swipes, an effort to keep the prince on his toes, but his foot had caught on the uneven ground. He’d gone down hard, the impact tearing his tunic and baring his back for the briefest of moments. That moment was all it took for Arthur to see the scars—jagged, angry lines crisscrossing Merlin’s pale skin.

“Merlin!” Arthur’s voice was sharp, tinged with an emotion he couldn’t quite place. “What are those?”

Merlin scrambled to his feet, hastily pulling his tunic back into place. “Nothing, Sire. Just old wounds.”

“Old wounds?” Arthur’s eyes narrowed. “They look fresh. Who did this to you?”

“It’s nothing,” Merlin insisted, but his eyes betrayed him. They were wide, filled with a mix of fear and something else—something that looked a lot like shame.

“Merlin, I command you to tell me,” Arthur said, his voice dropping to a softer, yet no less authoritative tone. “Who did this to you?”

Merlin hesitated, his gaze dropping to the ground. “It’s a long story,” he muttered.

Arthur crossed his arms over his chest, his expression unyielding. “I’m not going anywhere.”

With a heavy sigh, Merlin sat down on a nearby log, the firelight casting shadows across his face. “It’s not just one person,” he began, his voice barely above a whisper. “It’s... it’s magic.”

Arthur’s heart skipped a beat. “Magic?”

Merlin nodded, his eyes meeting Arthur’s with a mixture of defiance and resignation. “I’ve been hiding it for years. Ever since I came to Camelot. But... but these scars, they’re from the times I couldn’t hide it. When I had to use magic to protect you, to protect Camelot.”

Arthur’s mind raced, piecing together fragments of memories, moments that had never quite made sense until now. “You’ve been using magic? For me?”

“Yes,” Merlin admitted, his voice breaking. “I know it’s forbidden, but I couldn’t let you die. I couldn’t let Camelot fall.”

For a moment, Arthur was silent, the weight of Merlin’s confession settling over him like a heavy cloak. “Why didn’t you tell me?” he asked finally, his voice thick with emotion.

“Because I knew what you’d say,” Merlin replied, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. “I knew you’d hate me.”

Arthur’s heart ached at the raw vulnerability in Merlin’s voice. “I could never hate you,” he said softly. “You’re my friend. My best friend.”

Merlin looked up, hope flickering in his eyes. “Really?”

“Really,” Arthur affirmed. He reached out, placing a hand on Merlin’s shoulder. “But I need to understand, Merlin. I need to know everything.”

And so, Merlin began to tell him. He spoke of the dragon Kilgharrah, of the prophecies and the destiny that had bound them together from the start. He spoke of the countless times he had used magic to save Arthur’s life, of the dangers he had faced and the sacrifices he had made. And as he spoke, Arthur listened, his heart swelling with a mixture of pride and sorrow.

When Merlin finally fell silent, Arthur felt as though he had been handed the pieces of a puzzle he hadn’t even known existed. “You’ve done so much for me,” he said, his voice filled with awe. “And I never knew.”

“I didn’t want you to know,” Merlin said quietly. “I didn’t want you to have to carry that burden.”

“But it’s not just your burden,” Arthur replied firmly. “We’re in this together. We always have been.”

Merlin’s eyes widened, a tentative smile tugging at the corners of his mouth. “Together?”

“Together,” Arthur repeated, his tone leaving no room for doubt. “From now on, we face everything together. No more secrets.”

Merlin nodded, a sense of peace washing over him for the first time in years. “No more secrets.”

As they sat there, side by side, the fire crackling softly in the background, Arthur felt a new sense of determination settle within him. The bond between them had been tested, but it had emerged stronger than ever. And he knew, without a doubt, that they could face whatever challenges lay ahead—together.

---

The next morning, Arthur was up early, the events of the previous night still fresh in his mind. He found Merlin in the courtyard, tending to the horses. It was a mundane task, but Arthur saw it differently now. He saw the sacrifices Merlin had made, the risks he had taken, all while performing the duties of a simple servant.

“Merlin,” Arthur called out, approaching him.

Merlin looked up, his expression wary. “Yes, Sire?”

Arthur shook his head. “No more of that. Just Arthur.”

Merlin’s eyes widened in surprise. “Arthur?”

“Yes,” Arthur said firmly. “We’re equals, Merlin. You’ve proven that time and time again.”

Merlin’s lips curved into a hesitant smile. “Thank you, Arthur.”

Arthur nodded, a smile of his own forming. “Now, I have a proposition for you.”

“Oh?” Merlin’s curiosity was piqued.

“I want you to be my advisor,” Arthur said, his tone leaving no room for argument. “You know more about magic and destiny than anyone. And I need someone I can trust by my side.”

Merlin’s mouth fell open in shock. “Advisor? But... but what about—”

“Father?” Arthur finished for him. “We’ll deal with him together. He needs to understand that magic isn’t inherently evil. And who better to show him than you?”

Merlin’s heart swelled with gratitude and pride. “I’d be honored, Arthur.”

“Good,” Arthur said, clapping him on the back. “Now, let’s get to work. We have a kingdom to protect.”

As they walked towards the castle, side by side, Merlin couldn’t help but feel a sense of hope. For the first time, he wasn’t alone in his fight. Arthur knew the truth, and he still stood by him. It was more than Merlin had ever dared to dream.

---

Weeks turned into months, and Arthur and Merlin’s bond only grew stronger. They faced countless challenges together, from rogue sorcerers to political intrigue, but they always emerged victorious. Arthur’s trust in Merlin never wavered, and Merlin found himself more confident in his magic and his place by Arthur’s side.

One evening, as they sat in Arthur’s chambers, poring over maps and strategies, Arthur looked up, his expression thoughtful. “Do you ever regret it?” he asked suddenly.

“Regret what?” Merlin replied, glancing up from the map.

“Everything,” Arthur said, gesturing vaguely. “The magic, the secrets, the danger. Do you ever wish you could have a normal life?”

Merlin considered the question, his gaze distant. “Sometimes,” he admitted. “But then I remember why I’m doing it. I remember you, and Camelot, and everything we’ve built together. And I know it’s worth it.”

Arthur’s eyes softened. “Thank you, Merlin. For everything.”

Merlin smiled, a warm, genuine smile. “You don’t have to thank me, Arthur. I’m just doing what I was meant to do.”

Arthur reached across the table, grasping Merlin’s hand. “And I’m grateful for it. Every day.”

In that moment, as their hands clasped together, Arthur knew that their bond was unbreakable. They had faced the darkness and emerged into the light, stronger and more united than ever. And as long as they stood together, there was nothing they couldn’t overcome.

---

The news spread quickly through the castle: Arthur had appointed Merlin as his advisor. Reactions were mixed, but Arthur stood firm in his decision. He faced his father with unwavering resolve, explaining the truth about Merlin’s magic and the countless times it had saved them all.

King Uther was furious, but Arthur’s determination and Merlin’s unwavering loyalty eventually won him over. It wasn’t an easy transition, but slowly, the people of Camelot began to see the benefits of having a sorcerer in their midst.

Merlin’s knowledge of magic became an invaluable asset, and his presence by Arthur’s side brought a new sense of hope to the kingdom. Together, they worked to create a more just and fair Camelot, one where magic wasn’t feared but respected.

As the years passed, Arthur and Merlin’s bond only deepened. They faced trials and tribulations, but they always came out stronger on the other side. Their friendship was the foundation upon which Camelot’s future was built, and it was a future filled with promise and possibility.

One night, as they stood on the castle battlements, looking out over the kingdom they had fought so hard to protect, Arthur turned to Merlin with a smile. “Do you remember the day I found out about your magic?”

Merlin chuckled. “How could I forget? I thought you were going to throw me in the dungeons.”

Arthur laughed. “I almost did. But I’m glad I didn’t.”

“Me too,” Merlin said, his voice filled with gratitude.

Arthur’s expression turned serious. “I want you to know, Merlin, that I wouldn’t be here without you. Camelot wouldn’t be here without you.”

Merlin’s eyes shone with emotion. “And I wouldn’t be here without you, Arthur. You’ve given me a place, a purpose. You’ve given me a home.”

Arthur reached out, pulling Merlin into a tight embrace. “We’ve given each other everything,” he said softly. “And as long as we stand together, there’s nothing we can’t achieve.”

As they stood there, wrapped in each other’s warmth, the future stretched out before them—bright, hopeful, and filled with endless possibilities. And they knew, without a doubt, that they would face it all together, side by side, as they always had.

For in the end, it wasn’t the magic or the destiny that defined them. It was their bond, their friendship, and the unbreakable trust they had in each other. And that, above all else, was what made them unstoppable.

writing_prompt: A scruffy young raven, outcast by her kin, takes up residence in your chambers, much to the dismay of your court. But as the bird grows into a striking and mischievous companion, you realize she may be more than just a pet—she's family.
story:
Thorin Oakenshield had never expected his chambers to be invaded by a bird, of all creatures. The raven was scruffy and small, with feathers that were more gray than black and a beady eye that seemed to size him up with an unsettling intelligence. It flitted in one day through the high windows of Erebor, settling itself on the back of his armchair with an air of defiance, as if daring anyone to challenge its presence.

"Where did you come from?" Thorin muttered, narrowing his eyes at the bird.

The raven cocked its head and let out a sharp caw, almost as if in response. Thorin could have sworn he saw a glint of amusement in its eye. He shook his head and returned to the maps spread out on his desk, trying to ignore the persistent gaze of his new visitor.

Days passed, and the raven showed no signs of leaving. It followed Thorin everywhere, perching on his shoulder during council meetings, much to the dismay of his advisors. Balin, ever the diplomat, attempted to shoo the bird away with gentle words and gestures, but the raven merely ruffled its feathers and settled more comfortably on Thorin's shoulder.

"It's becoming quite the nuisance, Thorin," Balin said one day, his voice tinged with exasperation. "The others are starting to talk."

Thorin merely shrugged, a small smile playing at the corners of his lips. "Let them talk. She's not hurting anyone."

The raven let out a triumphant caw, as if it understood it had won this round. Balin sighed and shook his head, muttering something about stubborn kings and their strange companions.

As the weeks turned into months, the raven grew more striking. Its feathers darkened to a glossy black, and its eyes gleamed with an almost mischievous light. It had a knack for causing trouble, stealing shiny trinkets from the treasure hoard and hiding them in Thorin's chambers, much to the amusement of the king. Thorin found himself talking to the bird more and more, sharing his thoughts and worries in the quiet hours of the night.

"You remind me of someone," Thorin said one evening, the firelight casting a warm glow on his face. The raven was perched on the arm of his chair, watching him intently. "Fíli, I think. Always so curious, always getting into trouble."

The raven cawed softly, as if in agreement. Thorin chuckled, reaching out to gently stroke its feathers. "Yes, you have his spirit. I wonder if you were sent to me for a reason."

It was during one of these quiet moments that Kíli, Thorin's nephew, found him. The young dwarf had been looking for his uncle, a matter of some urgency on his mind. But when he saw the raven perched on Thorin's shoulder, his eyes widened in surprise.

"Uncle, what is that?" Kíli asked, pointing at the bird.

Thorin looked up, a soft smile on his face. "This, Kíli, is my new companion. She seems to have taken a liking to me."

Kíli approached cautiously, his curiosity piqued. "Does she have a name?"

Thorin paused, considering. "Not yet. What do you think we should call her?"

Kíli tilted his head, studying the raven. "How about Mithril? Her feathers shine like the precious metal."

Thorin nodded thoughtfully. "Mithril it is, then."

Mithril cawed in approval, flapping her wings as if to show off her new name. Kíli laughed, reaching out to gently stroke her feathers. "She's beautiful, Uncle. And clever, too, if she's managed to win you over."

Thorin chuckled, a warmth spreading through his chest. "Yes, she is. And she's more than just a pet, I think. She's family."

As time went on, Mithril's presence became a source of comfort for Thorin. She was there during the long, lonely nights when the weight of kingship threatened to crush him. She listened without judgment as he spoke of his fears and doubts, her beady eyes filled with a quiet understanding.

It was during one of these nights that Thorin confided in Mithril about his greatest fear: losing his family. The memory of his father and grandfather's madness haunted him, and he worried that he, too, would succumb to the same fate.

"I don't want to become like them," Thorin whispered, his voice barely audible. "I don't want to lose myself."

Mithril cawed softly, as if trying to reassure him. She nuzzled her head against his cheek, her feathers soft and warm. Thorin closed his eyes, taking comfort in her presence.

"You won't let that happen, will you?" he murmured. "You'll keep me grounded."

Mithril cawed again, a promise in her voice. And for the first time in a long while, Thorin felt a glimmer of hope.

The court, however, was not so easily convinced. Rumors spread like wildfire, whispers of a mad king who talked to birds. Thorin's advisors grew increasingly concerned, their patience wearing thin.

One day, Dwalin approached Thorin with a look of determination. "Thorin, we need to talk."

Thorin looked up from his maps, a frown creasing his brow. "What is it, Dwalin?"

"It's about that bird of yours," Dwalin said, his voice firm. "The others are worried. They think it's affecting your judgment."

Thorin's eyes darkened, a flash of anger crossing his face. "Mithril is not affecting my judgment. She is a companion, nothing more."

Dwalin held his ground, his gaze steady. "I understand that, Thorin. But you have to see it from their perspective. They fear for your sanity."

Thorin's anger dissipated, replaced by a weariness that seemed to seep into his very bones. "I know they worry. But Mithril has been a source of comfort for me. She reminds me of what truly matters."

Dwalin sighed, his expression softening. "I know, old friend. But you need to show them that you are still the strong leader they believe in. Perhaps... perhaps it's time to let Mithril go."

Thorin's heart clenched at the thought, but he knew Dwalin was right. With a heavy heart, he nodded. "Very well. I will find a way to release her."

That evening, Thorin sat by the fire, Mithril perched on his shoulder. He stroked her feathers, his heart aching. "I have to let you go, Mithril," he whispered. "It's for the good of my people."

Mithril cawed softly, as if understanding his words. She nuzzled her head against his cheek, a gesture of farewell. Thorin closed his eyes, a single tear slipping down his face.

The next morning, Thorin stood on the balcony of Erebor, the wind tugging at his hair. Mithril perched on the railing, her eyes fixed on him. "Fly free, Mithril," he said softly. "Find your kin."

With a final caw, Mithril spread her wings and took to the sky, soaring high above the mountains. Thorin watched her go, a sense of loss settling in his chest. But he knew it was the right thing to do.

Months passed, and life in Erebor returned to a semblance of normalcy. Thorin threw himself into his duties, his mind focused on the needs of his people. But he never forgot Mithril, and the comfort she had brought him.

It was on a cold winter's night that Thorin heard a familiar caw outside his window. His heart leaped, and he rushed to the window, throwing it open. There, perched on the sill, was Mithril, her feathers gleaming in the moonlight.

"Mithril," Thorin breathed, a smile spreading across his face. "You've come back."

Mithril cawed in response, flapping her wings. Thorin reached out, and she hopped onto his arm, nuzzling her head against his cheek. Tears filled his eyes as he realized that she had chosen to return to him.

"Welcome home, Mithril," he whispered, his voice choked with emotion. "Welcome home."

From that day forward, Mithril remained by Thorin's side, a constant source of strength and comfort. The court, seeing the bond between king and raven, grew to accept her presence, and even came to appreciate the mischievous bird's antics.

Thorin's heart healed, the weight of his fears lifting as he embraced the love and support of his family—both dwarf and raven. And in the quiet moments, when the world seemed too heavy to bear, Mithril was there to remind him that he was never truly alone.

As the years passed, Mithril's legend grew, her loyalty to Thorin becoming a symbol of hope and resilience for the people of Erebor. And Thorin, with his faithful companion by his side, led his kingdom with a renewed sense of purpose and strength.

For in the end, it was not the crown or the treasure that defined him, but the bonds of love and family that had carried him through the darkest of times. And in Mithril, he had found a family member who had taught him the true meaning of loyalty and companionship.

And so, the story of the scruffy young raven who had taken up residence in the king's chambers became a cherished tale in Erebor, a testament to the power of love and the unbreakable bonds that tie us all together.

writing_prompt: On the coldest night of the year, Merlin braves the frost to gather a rare herb, only to find himself summoned to Arthur's chambers. What begins as a simple scolding over his lack of winter gear turns into an unexpectedly tender moment by the fire.
story:
Merlin shivered violently as he trudged through the snow-covered forest, the wind howling around him like a banshee. His breath left his lips in white clouds, and his fingers, despite being tightly wrapped in his threadbare gloves, felt numb to the bone. All for a single herb, the rare and elusive frostflower that only bloomed on the coldest night of the year. Gaius had been adamant that they needed it for a potion, and Merlin, ever the dutiful apprentice, had ventured out into the icy wilderness without a second thought.

The moon hung high in the sky, casting an ethereal glow on the snow-laden trees. Merlin’s eyes scanned the ground, searching for the telltale glimmer of the frostflower’s delicate petals. He crouched down, his knees sinking into the snow, and finally spotted the small, star-shaped bloom nestled among the roots of an ancient oak.

“Got you,” Merlin murmured, gingerly plucking the herb and tucking it into a small pouch at his belt. He stood up, his joints protesting from the cold, and started the long trek back to Camelot. The warmth of the castle seemed like a distant dream, and he could almost feel the heat of the hearth on his frozen skin.

By the time he reached the castle gates, Merlin was barely able to keep his teeth from chattering. The guards gave him curious looks but did not stop him as he made his way through the courtyard and into the relative warmth of the stone corridors. He was halfway to Gaius’s chambers when a stern voice called out his name.

“Merlin!”

Merlin turned to see Sir Leon striding towards him, his expression a mix of irritation and concern. “What on earth are you doing out in this weather?” Leon demanded, his brow furrowed.

“I was... uh, gathering herbs for Gaius,” Merlin stammered, his breath still coming in short gasps.

Leon shook his head. “You look half-frozen. Get yourself to the kitchens and warm up before you catch your death.”

Merlin nodded gratefully and hurried off, but before he could reach the sanctuary of the kitchens, another voice, this one even more commanding, stopped him in his tracks.

“Merlin!”

Arthur stood at the entrance to his chambers, his arms crossed and a look of exasperation on his face. “What are you doing running around in this weather without proper winter gear?” he demanded.

Merlin opened his mouth to respond, but the words froze on his tongue as Arthur grabbed him by the arm and pulled him into his chambers. The warmth hit Merlin like a physical force, and he stumbled slightly as Arthur guided him towards the roaring fire.

“Sit,” Arthur ordered, pushing Merlin down onto a cushioned chair. “You’re going to get yourself killed one of these days, you know that?”

Merlin couldn’t help but smile despite his chattering teeth. “Wouldn’t be the first time someone’s said that,” he quipped, earning a glare from Arthur.

Arthur turned away and began rummaging through a chest at the foot of his bed. He pulled out a thick woolen blanket and tossed it to Merlin. “Wrap yourself in this,” he said, his tone softening slightly. “And take off those wet clothes before you catch a chill.”

Merlin hesitated for a moment but then complied, stripping off his soaked jacket and gloves and wrapping the blanket tightly around himself. The fire’s warmth seeped into his bones, and he sighed in relief.

Arthur sat down in the chair opposite him, his expression unreadable. “Why were you out there, Merlin?” he asked, his voice low.

“I told you, I was gathering herbs for Gaius,” Merlin replied, holding up the pouch with the frostflower. “He needed this for a potion, and it only blooms on the coldest night of the year.”

Arthur’s frown deepened. “And he sent you out there alone? In this weather?”

Merlin shrugged. “It had to be done. Besides, I can take care of myself.”

Arthur snorted. “Clearly.” He leaned back in his chair, his eyes fixed on the fire. “You’re too reckless for your own good, Merlin.”

Merlin chuckled softly. “I’ve heard that before, too.”

For a few moments, they sat in silence, the only sound the crackling of the fire. Merlin could feel the tension slowly ebbing away, replaced by an unexpected sense of comfort. He glanced at Arthur, noticing the way the firelight danced in his eyes, casting shadows on his face.

“You know,” Arthur said suddenly, breaking the silence, “you don’t have to do everything on your own. You could have asked for help.”

Merlin looked down at his hands, feeling a pang of guilt. “I didn’t want to burden anyone,” he admitted. “And I didn’t think it was that dangerous.”

Arthur shook his head. “You’re an idiot,” he said, but there was no malice in his voice. “A brave, selfless idiot, but an idiot nonetheless.”

Merlin couldn’t help but smile. “Thanks, I think.”

Arthur sighed and ran a hand through his hair. “Just promise me you’ll be more careful next time,” he said, his tone serious. “I can’t afford to lose you, Merlin.”

Merlin’s heart skipped a beat at the sincerity in Arthur’s voice. “I promise,” he said softly.

Arthur nodded, satisfied. He stood up and walked over to a small table, pouring two cups of steaming hot tea. He handed one to Merlin and took a sip from his own cup. “So, tell me more about this herb,” he said, his tone lighter. “What’s it for?”

Merlin took a grateful sip of the tea, feeling the warmth spread through his body. “It’s called a frostflower,” he explained. “Gaius needs it for a potion to help with frostbite and hypothermia. It’s incredibly rare and only blooms on the coldest night of the year.”

Arthur raised an eyebrow. “And you went out to get it without any proper winter gear?”

Merlin shrugged. “I didn’t think it would be that bad,” he said sheepishly.

Arthur shook his head in disbelief. “You’re unbelievable, Merlin.”

Merlin grinned. “I aim to please.”

Arthur chuckled and took another sip of his tea. “You certainly do.”

They lapsed into a comfortable silence, the tension from earlier completely gone. Merlin felt a sense of contentment he hadn’t felt in a long time, and he couldn’t help but think that maybe, just maybe, this was where he belonged.

As the fire crackled and the warmth of the tea seeped into his bones, Merlin realized that this moment, this simple, tender moment by the fire, was worth all the cold and discomfort he had endured. He glanced at Arthur, who was staring into the flames with a thoughtful expression, and felt a surge of affection for the prince.

“Thank you, Arthur,” Merlin said softly.

Arthur looked up, surprised. “For what?”

“For caring,” Merlin replied. “For always looking out for me.”

Arthur’s expression softened, and he smiled. “Someone has to keep you out of trouble,” he said. “And besides, you’re my friend, Merlin. Of course I care.”

Merlin’s heart swelled with warmth at Arthur’s words. “I care about you too, Arthur,” he said sincerely.

Arthur’s smile widened, and for a moment, they simply sat there, basking in the warmth of the fire and the comfort of each other’s company.

“Promise me something, Merlin,” Arthur said after a while.

“Anything,” Merlin replied.

“Promise me you won’t do anything that reckless again,” Arthur said, his tone serious. “I don’t want to lose you.”

Merlin nodded, his eyes locking with Arthur’s. “I promise,” he said firmly.

Arthur looked relieved, and he leaned back in his chair, a contented smile on his face. “Good,” he said. “Now, how about we finish this tea and get some rest? We’ve got a long day ahead of us tomorrow.”

Merlin nodded, feeling a sense of peace settle over him. “That sounds like a good idea.”

As they finished their tea and settled in for the night, Merlin couldn’t help but feel grateful for this unexpected moment of connection with Arthur. It was a reminder that even in the coldest, darkest times, there was always warmth and light to be found in the bonds of friendship.

And as he drifted off to sleep, wrapped in the warmth of the blanket and the comfort of Arthur’s presence, Merlin knew that he would face whatever challenges lay ahead with renewed strength and determination. Because no matter what, he had Arthur by his side, and that was all he needed.

The fire crackled softly in the hearth, casting a warm glow over the room, and the cold, dark night seemed a little less daunting with the promise of tomorrow and the strength of their friendship to guide them through.

As Merlin slipped into a peaceful slumber, he felt a sense of hope and contentment that he hadn’t felt in a long time. And he knew that, no matter what the future held, he and Arthur would face it together, side by side, just as they always had.

For in the heart of winter’s chill, they had found a warmth that would carry them through even the darkest of nights. And that, Merlin knew, was the true magic of their bond.

writing_prompt: When Bilbo Baggins left the Shire for his grand adventure, Lobelia Sackville-Baggins saw an opportunity to claim Bag End for herself. But when news of Bilbo's unexpected fate reaches Hobbiton, her plans—and her pride—are thrown into chaos.
story:
Bag End had always been Lobelia Sackville-Baggins' dream. The grandest smial in all of Hobbiton, it was a beacon of prestige, comfort, and, most importantly, status. When Bilbo Baggins, that queer, adventurous hobbit, left the Shire with a company of dwarves, Lobelia saw her chance. 

As she stood in front of the round green door, her heart pounded with a mix of excitement and trepidation. She was dressed in her finest, the lace on her bonnet crisp and her gloves spotless. Her husband, Otho, stood beside her, looking every bit the picture of nervous support. 

“Well, here we are,” Otho said, trying to sound confident. “Bag End.”

“Yes,” Lobelia replied, her voice barely above a whisper. She reached out and touched the door, feeling the smooth, painted wood under her fingertips. This was it. Her moment. 

They pushed open the door, and the interior of Bag End greeted them with a cozy, inviting warmth. The hearth was dark, the rooms silent, but there was an unmistakable charm to the place. It was as if the very walls whispered of stories and adventures, secrets and histories.

Lobelia and Otho wasted no time. They moved through the rooms, taking stock of Bilbo’s belongings. Every corner, every cupboard, was scrutinized. 

“Once we’ve cleared out his things, it will truly be ours,” Lobelia said, with a determination that brooked no argument. 

But just as they were starting to feel at home, a knock at the door startled them. Lobelia hurried to open it, and there stood Hamfast Gamgee, the gardener. 

“Begging your pardon, ma’am,” Hamfast said, doffing his cap, “but there’s news from Bree. Word is that Mister Bilbo’s had an accident.”

Lobelia’s heart skipped a beat. “An accident?” she asked, trying to sound concerned but unable to hide the flicker of hope in her eyes. If Bilbo was truly gone, Bag End would be theirs without contest.

“Aye,” Hamfast said, his face solemn. “A letter came from a dwarf—Thorin Oakenshield, I believe. It says Mister Bilbo’s been lost in the mountains. They searched, but they couldn’t find him.”

Otho placed a comforting hand on his wife's shoulder, but Lobelia barely noticed. Her mind was spinning. Bilbo gone? Truly gone? She had always thought it would take years, perhaps even a lifetime, to wrest Bag End from him. But now…

“Thank you for the news, Hamfast,” she managed to say. “You may return to your duties.”

As the gardener left, Lobelia turned to her husband, her eyes gleaming. “Do you realize what this means?”

Otho nodded slowly. “Bag End is ours.”

For weeks, Lobelia lived in a state of euphoria. She busied herself with redecorating, making grand plans for gatherings and dinners that would cement her status as the new lady of Bag End. She even began to imagine the admiring looks from the other hobbits, the whispered compliments and envious glances.

But then, as news traveled slowly through the Shire, rumors began to surface. It seemed that Bilbo’s fate was not as clear-cut as they had first thought. 

One evening, as Lobelia and Otho sat by the fire, there came another knock at the door. This time, it was a dwarf—a stout, dark-haired fellow with a serious expression.

“Good evening,” the dwarf said, bowing slightly. “I am Balin, one of the company that traveled with Bilbo. I bring news from Erebor.”

Lobelia’s heart sank. “What news?” she asked, her voice tight.

“Bilbo is alive,” Balin said simply. “He was found by eagles and brought to safety. He is recovering and will return to the Shire soon.”

The room seemed to spin around Lobelia. Alive? Returning? All her dreams of Bag End, all her plans, were crumbling before her eyes.

“But… but he was lost!” she stammered. “The letter said—”

“The letter was mistaken,” Balin interrupted gently. “We thought him lost, but he survived. He is a remarkable hobbit, your cousin.”

Lobelia could barely breathe. She felt as if the walls of Bag End were closing in on her, mocking her ambitions. How could this be happening?

When Balin left, she sank into a chair, her face pale. Otho tried to comfort her, but she pushed him away.

“What are we going to do?” she whispered. “We can’t just give it all up, not after everything.”

“We’ll have to,” Otho said softly. “Bag End belongs to Bilbo. We knew that when we came here.”

The days that followed were a blur of bitterness and resentment. Lobelia continued to hold onto the hope that Bilbo might change his mind, might decide to stay in Erebor or go on another adventure. But that hope was dashed when a letter arrived from Bilbo himself, thanking the Sackville-Bagginses for looking after his home and announcing his imminent return.

The day Bilbo walked back through the front door of Bag End, he was greeted by a scene of quiet chaos. Lobelia stood in the hallway, her face a mask of forced politeness.

“Bilbo,” she said, her voice strained. “Welcome home.”

Bilbo looked around, his eyes taking in the changes she had made. “Lobelia, Otho,” he said, nodding to each of them. “Thank you for keeping the place in order.”

Lobelia felt a surge of anger. How dare he be so calm, so gracious, when he was taking everything from her?

“We’ve done our best,” she replied, barely able to keep the bitterness out of her voice.

Bilbo smiled, but there was a sadness in his eyes. “I appreciate it. Truly.”

As the days passed, Lobelia found herself in a strange limbo. She couldn’t bear to stay in Bag End, but she couldn’t bring herself to leave. She watched Bilbo from a distance, seeing him settle back into his old routines, his presence a constant reminder of her thwarted dreams.

One afternoon, as she stood in the garden, she heard a voice behind her.

“Lobelia.”

She turned to see Bilbo, his face thoughtful. “I wanted to talk to you.”

“What about?” she asked, her tone defensive.

Bilbo sighed. “I know you’ve always wanted Bag End. And I know my leaving must have seemed like an opportunity.”

Lobelia felt a flush of shame. “You don’t understand,” she said. “This place… it’s everything I’ve ever wanted.”

“I do understand,” Bilbo replied gently. “But Bag End is more than just a house. It’s a home, filled with memories and stories. I couldn’t bear to see it changed beyond recognition.”

For a moment, they stood in silence, the weight of unspoken words hanging between them.

“I’m not going to throw you out,” Bilbo said finally. “I want you to stay. As long as you need.”

Lobelia looked at him, her eyes filling with tears. “Why would you do that?”

“Because,” Bilbo said, “we’re family. And family takes care of each other.”

As the days turned into weeks, Lobelia began to see Bag End in a new light. It was still the home she had always dreamed of, but it was also a place of kindness and generosity, a place where even the most unexpected of bonds could be formed.

And in the end, that was worth more than all the status and prestige in the world.
